title: 105_hr4431
content: The "HIV Partner Protection Act" is cited as the short title. It amends the Public Health Service Act to include a section on partner notification for HIV health care services. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" amends the Public Health Service Act to require states to implement partner notification programs for individuals with HIV disease. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" mandates partner notification programs for individuals with HIV disease. Health entities must report positive test results to the State public health officer, including the individual's name. Partners are given the opportunity to learn about potential exposure to the disease. The HIV Partner Protection Act mandates partner notification programs for individuals with HIV disease. Partners are provided with an opportunity to learn about potential exposure to the disease without revealing the identity of infected individuals. Counseling and testing for HIV are available to partners and infected individuals. The HIV Partner Protection Act mandates partner notification programs for individuals with HIV disease. Counseling and testing on HIV disease are available to partners and infected individuals, including information on modes of transmission and therapeutic measures. The HIV Partner Protection Act mandates counseling, referrals, and in-person notifications for infected individuals and their partners. No penalties are imposed for non-compliance. Notifications under the HIV Partner Protection Act are provided in person unless it is an unreasonable burden on the State. There are no penalties for infected individuals who choose not to identify their partners or for individuals who make errors in reporting or disclosing information. The HIV Partner Protection Act ensures no penalties for errors in reporting or disclosing information under the program. Failure to notify partners does not result in civil liability for health entities reporting to the State. The program's provisions cannot be interpreted as prohibiting State actions. The State must report the identity of infected individuals under the program without their consent. State insurance laws require testing for HIV without penalties for reporting errors. State insurance laws must prohibit insurers from penalizing individuals who undergo testing for HIV disease. State insurance laws prohibit insurers from taking action against individuals solely based on HIV testing. Definitions for "infected individual" are provided in this section. The section defines "infected individual" as someone with HIV disease and includes partners at risk of HIV transmission through various means. The section defines "infected individual" as someone with HIV disease and includes partners at risk of HIV transmission through various means, such as sharing hypodermic needles for drug injection and drug-related paraphernalia. The requirements described in subsections (a) and (b) are delayed for certain states without regular legislative sessions in fiscal years 1999 and 2000. In states without regular legislative sessions in fiscal years 1999 and 2000, the requirements for receiving a grant under this part will only apply for fiscal year 2001 and subsequent years. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may provide grants to States to assist with the costs of implementing partner notification programs for HIV, as required by the Public Health Service Act. $10,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated annually from 2000 to 2004 for this purpose.
